content.title: Chest Tube Management
content.summary: Chest tube (tube thoracostomy) is a critical procedure for drainage of the pleural space. Indications include pneumothorax, hemothorax, pleural effusion requiring drainage, and empyema. Proper management involves understanding water-seal systems, recognizing complications, and determining appropriate timing for removal.
key_points: Indications: pneumothorax, hemothorax, empyema, large pleural effusions
Insertion site: 4th-5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line (triangle of safety)
Water-seal chamber: allows air out but prevents re-entry
Continuous tidaling indicates patent tube connected to pleural space
Air leak: bubbling in water-seal chamber during expiration/cough
Removal criteria: air leak resolved, <150-200 mL/day drainage, lung re-expanded
content.statement: Chest tube management encompasses proper insertion, monitoring of water-seal drainage systems, recognizing complications, and determining readiness for removal based on output, air leak status, and lung re-expansion.

explanation.intuition: A chest tube is like a drain in a bathtub - it removes unwanted fluid or air from the pleural space. The water-seal system acts as a one-way valve: the tube lets stuff out but the water blocks anything from going back in. Bubbling means there's an air leak somewhere; tidaling (water rising and falling with breathing) means the tube is working properly.
explanation.key_insight: The key to chest tube management is understanding what the water-seal chamber is telling you. Continuous bubbling = air leak from the lung. No tidaling = tube clogged or kinked. Bloody output >200 mL/hr may indicate hemothorax requiring surgical exploration.
explanation.technical_details: Three-chamber systems: collection chamber (drains fluid), water-seal chamber (-2 cm H2O acts as one-way valve), suction control chamber (-20 cm H2O suction). Digital systems have replaced traditional water-seal in many centers, providing continuous air leak monitoring.

definitions_glossary.tube_thoracostomy: Insertion of chest tube for pleural drainage; formal term for chest tube placement
definitions_glossary.triangle_of_safety: Anatomic region for safe chest tube insertion: lateral to pectoralis major, anterior to latissimus dorsi, above 5th intercostal space
definitions_glossary.water_seal_chamber: Component that allows one-way flow; air exits but cannot re-enter pleural space
definitions_glossary.tidaling: Oscillation of water level with respiration; indicates patent tube and pleural space connection
definitions_glossary.air_leak: Bubbling in water-seal chamber indicating ongoing bronchopleural communication
definitions_glossary.suction_control: Typically -20 cm H2O; facilitates pleural apposition and lung re-expansion
definitions_glossary.empyema: Infected pleural fluid requiring chest tube drainage and often surgical decortication
definitions_glossary.hemothorax: Blood in pleural space; massive if >1500 mL or >200 mL/hr ongoing
definitions_glossary.tension_pneumothorax: Life-threatening air under pressure; needle decompression then chest tube
definitions_glossary.bronchopleural_fistula: Persistent air leak from lung communicating with pleural space
definitions_glossary.pigtail_catheter: Small-bore (8-14 Fr) drain for simple effusions or pneumothorax; less painful
definitions_glossary.decortication: Surgical removal of fibrous pleural peel in chronic empyema

pathophysiology.mechanism: Restore negative intrapleural pressure by evacuating air, fluid, or blood

hemothorax.massive: >1500 mL initial output or >200 mL/hr requires surgical exploration

pleural_effusion.indications: Large symptomatic effusions, empyema, malignant effusions for pleurodesis

empyema.management: Chest tube drainage ± fibrinolytics; VATS decortication if organized

pre_procedure.imaging: CXR or US to confirm effusion/pneumothorax location
pre_procedure.labs: Coagulation studies if time permits; correct coagulopathy if possible
pre_procedure.consent: Discuss risks: pain, bleeding, infection, organ injury

monitoring.air_leak: Graded 1-7 scale on digital systems; document resolution
monitoring.tidaling: Confirms tube patency and pleural connection
monitoring.imaging: Post-insertion CXR to confirm position and lung expansion

differential_diagnosis: Clogged tube vs resolved air leak
Persistent air leak: bronchopleural fistula vs small peripheral leak

insertion_technique.technique: Blunt dissection, finger sweep, tube directed apically (pneumothorax) or basally (fluid)

drainage_management.water_seal: Standard for most patients after lung re-expansion
drainage_management.suction: -20 cm H2O for persistent air leak or incomplete expansion
drainage_management.ambulatory_devices: Heimlich valve or portable digital units for outpatient management

troubleshooting.no_drainage: Check for kinks, clots; may need flushing or replacement
troubleshooting.persistent_air_leak: Ensure all connections tight; may need prolonged drainage or VATS
troubleshooting.pain: Adequate analgesia including intercostal nerve block; PCA if needed

removal_criteria.pneumothorax: No air leak for 12-24 hours; lung fully expanded
removal_criteria.process: Trial of water seal (off suction) before removal; repeat CXR after removal

definition.@value: The insertion, monitoring, and removal of chest tubes used to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space

scopeNote.@value: Covers indications, insertion technique, drainage system principles, and removal criteria

medicalCode.description: Drainage of pleural cavity, percutaneous approach
Tube thoracostomy with or without water seal

learning_objectives: Identify indications for chest tube placement
Describe the components and function of water-seal drainage systems
Interpret chest tube output and air leak status
Recognize complications of chest tube placement
Apply criteria for safe chest tube removal
clinical_pearls: Tidaling = patent tube; absent tidaling = kinked, clogged, or lung expanded
Continuous air leak + no lung expansion = may need surgery (bronchopleural fistula)
Hemothorax >1500 mL initial OR >200 mL/hr = likely needs thoracotomy
Small-bore catheters work for most simple effusions and pneumothoraces
Always get post-removal CXR to check for recurrent pneumothorax
common_misconceptions: Bigger tube is always better - small bore works for many cases
Clamping chest tube is safe for transport - generally avoid clamping
Air leak always needs surgery - most resolve with time and water seal
